items.title: Once shunned,  Saudi crown prince is Trump’s guest of honour. Canada is warming up, too
Alberta to invoke notwithstanding clause to shield 3 transgender bills from court challenges
Bo Bichette declines qualifying offer from Toronto Blue Jays
items.summary_auto: Bo Bichette has declined a qualifying offer from the Toronto Blue Jays, meaning the major-league veteran of seven seasons will opt to choose his next deal from what he is offered on the open market.

items.title: CRTC updates definition of Canadian content, putting limits on AI use
items.summary_auto: The federal broadcast regulator has released a new definition of Canadian content — and humans, not AI, must maintain creative control in order to qualify.

items.title: Ottawa Charge won't play at smaller Lansdowne arena, PWHL says
items.summary_auto: "We'd like to find a solution that works for us to stay in Ottawa," a league executive says of the Ottawa Charge. "But the city hasn't made it easy for us."

items.title: Is the U.S. starving for Canadian travellers? | About That
items.summary_auto: Canadian travel to the United States has dropped sharply since President Donald Trump retook office earlier this year. Andrew Chang breaks down the numbers to explain the impact on the U.S. economy, and how many American businesses are trying to win Canadians back. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Facebook owner Meta wins U.S. antitrust case, won't have to break off Instagram, WhatsApp
items.summary_auto: Meta has prevailed over an existential challenge to its business that could have forced the tech giant to spin off Instagram and WhatsApp after a judge ruled that the company does not hold a monopoly in social networking.

items.title: Alleged Ryan Wedding associate from Montreal faces murder charge, extradition to U.S.
items.summary_auto: A man alleged to have ties to organized crime in Montreal is facing charges in relation to a murder and cocaine trafficking, and is now facing extradition to the United States.

items.title: 20 people stuck in elevator at the deepest light-rail station in Canada — on 1st day of service
items.summary_auto: On the first day the new Deux-Montagnes line of Montreal’s light-rail network was officially in full operation, an elevator carrying commuters at Édouard-Montpetit station broke down for an hour.

items.title: Team Canada unveils athlete outfits for Milan-Cortina Olympics, Paralympics
A solid gold toilet called 'America' and reportedly worth millions, is up for auction
items.summary_auto: Art collectors have a chance Tuesday to buy one of the world's most lucrative latrines: a solid gold, fully functional toilet. The piece, by provocative Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan, goes up for auction Tuesday evening at Sotheby's in New York.

items.title: Proposal to ban raising of national flags at Calgary city hall delayed
items.summary_auto: The proposal, brought forward by Ward 13 Coun. Dan McLean, called for council to discuss amendments to Calgary's flag policy during its scheduled public hearing meeting as an "urgent business" matter.

items.title: Edmonton, Red Deer to co-host world junior hockey championship in 2027
items.summary_auto: Edmonton and Red Deer will host the 2027 world junior hockey championship after two previous plans to share the international tournament between the cities were scuttled by the COVID-19 pandemic.

items.title: Manitoba throne speech promises 1st supervised consumption site, overpass at site of deadly Carberry bus crash
items.summary_auto: Manitoba’s NDP government is promising to build, saying in its third throne speech that it will construct an overpass at the location of a bus crash that killed 17 seniors, set up the province’s first supervised consumption site and build a new fuel-burning generation station to stave off a forecast power shortage.

items.title: Manitoba throne speech promises supervised consumption site by January, overpass at site of deadly bus crash
items.summary_auto: Manitoba’s NDP government is promising to build, saying in its third throne speech that it will construct an overpass at the location of a bus crash that killed 17 seniors, set up the province’s first supervised consumption site and build a new fuel-burning generation station to stave off a forecast power shortage.

items.title: ‘Parasocial’ is Cambridge Dictionary's word of the year
items.summary_auto: If you felt more excited for Taylor Swift’s engagement announcement earlier this year than you did for your friend or family member’s, you might relate to Cambridge Dictionary’s word of 2025: "parasocial," which describes having a one-sided connection with someone you do not know, such as a celebrity, a fictional character or an AI chatbot.

items.title: WestJet weight cap on power wheelchairs leaves some Canadians grounded, advocates say
items.summary_auto: Travellers and advocates say a rule of the Calgary-based airline that bars mobility aids of more than 136 kilograms from most of its planes discriminates against people living with a disability.

items.title: Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande shine in good-enough Wicked: For Good
items.summary_auto: This isn’t to say the much-anticipated followup to 2024’s Oscar-nominated first outing of Wicked is a disappointment. At least not an abject one. It’s more or less competent, buoyed by undeniably incredible singing and framed by charmingly fantastical set design.

items.title: North Carolina becomes latest battleground as military-aided operations ebb in other cities
items.summary_auto: Federal immigration authorities could expand their enforcement action in North Carolina to a second city, as operations in other U.S. cities approved by Donald Trump's administration have either been deprioritized or caught up in legal limbo.

items.title: New home construction dropped 17% in October, says CMHC
items.summary_auto: The annual pace of housing starts, also known as new home construction, fell 17 per cent in October compared with September, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp. said on Tuesday.

items.title: Roblox increases safety guidelines with age verification, grouping users into age-based chats
items.summary_auto: The rules will make it so kids and teens can only message people within a similar age group to their own. The moves come as the popular gaming platform continues to face criticism and lawsuits over child safety and a growing number of countries and jurisdictions are implementing age verification laws.

items.title: Parents, doctors call for free RSV shots for all infants in B.C.
items.summary_auto: An infant immunization for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is now available across Canada, but it still has to be paid for out of pocket — and at a steep cost — by most parents in B.C.

items.title: L.A. County sheriff investigating new sex battery claim against Sean (Diddy) Combs
items.summary_auto: The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said Monday it's investigating a new sexual battery allegation against hip-hop mogul Sean (Diddy) Combs. The claim involves an unnamed music producer who says he was asked to come to a photo shoot in 2020 at a Los Angeles warehouse.

items.title: These farmers have a dream for the world’s most expensive spice, and it's rooted in Canadian soil
items.summary_auto: As golden hour settles over Avtar Dhillon’s farm in Abbotsford, B.C., rows of delicate purple flowers are in full bloom. Inside lies an ancient spice some Canadian farmers are beginning to get excited about.

items.title: Cloudflare restoring services after outage takes down ChatGPT, X, other sites
items.summary_auto: Internet infrastructure provider Cloudflare says it has identified an issue that caused outages for the social media platform X, some multiplayer games and ChatGPT.

items.title: Saudi crown prince MBS unaware of Khashoggi killing, Trump says in White House visit
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman knew nothing about the murder of U.S. resident and Saudi citizen Jamal Khashoggi.

items.title: Ontario’s most stolen vehicles of 2024 revealed
items.summary_auto: Équité Association reveals the most commonly and most frequently stolen cars in Ontario and the rest of Canada last year.

items.title: 2 Ukrainians working for Russia suspected of being involved in railway blast, Polish PM says
items.summary_auto: Two Ukrainian citizens working for Russia are suspected of blowing up a railway line in Poland over the weekend, Prime Minister Donald Tusk said Tuesday.

items.title: Chinese airlines offer refunds on Japan trips, Tokyo warns about travel to China as tensions run high
items.summary_auto: Japan has warned its citizens in China to step up safety precautions and avoid crowded places amid a deepening dispute between Asia's two largest economies over Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's comments on Taiwan.

items.title: John Main is Nunavut’s next premier
items.summary_auto: Members voted for John Main as premier Nunavut's 7th Assembly. They also voted for David Joanasie as Speaker.

items.title: How investigating Indigenous activists became a CSIS priority for at least a decade
items.summary_auto: Canada's spies subjected Indigenous activists to a series of “Native extremism” investigations for at least a decade beginning in 1988, in what internal documents show was a countrywide surveillance program that became more intrusive following the resistance at Kanehsatà:ke, or the Oka Crisis.

items.title: Shoppers Drug Mart billed $81M for MedsChecks in 2 years when COVID services waned
items.summary_auto: Shoppers Drug Mart billed the Ontario government’s MedsCheck program $81.2 million for medication reviews over a two-year period when some of its current and former pharmacists said they were facing “unethical” corporate pressure to meet targets for the professional service.

items.title: F-35 defenders launch counterattack against Swedish fighter jet proposal
items.summary_auto: Former high-ranking officers of the Canadian Armed Forces are mounting a defence of the planned acquisition of 88 American F-35 fighter jets, hoping to put an end to the ongoing courtship between the Canadian government and the Swedish firm Saab.
